'Î±-Linolenic acid' (ALA) is an organic compound found in many common vegetable
oils. In terms of its structure, it is named all-cis-9,12,15-octadecatrienoic
acid. {{cite web |author=Beare-Rogers |title=IUPAC Lexicon of
Lipid Nutrition |year=2001
|url=http://www.iupac.org/publications/pac/2001/pdf/7304x0685.pdf
| accessdate=22 February 2006
|format=pdf| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20060212173746/http://www.i-
upac.org/publications/pac/2001/pdf/7304x0685.pdf| archivedate= 12 February 2006
| deadurl= no}} In physiological literature, it is given the
name 18:3 (nâ3).

Î±-Linolenic acid is a carboxylic acid with an 18-carbon chain and three [[Cis-
trans isomerism|cis]] double bonds. The first double bond is located at the
third carbon from the methyl end of the fatty acid chain, known as the n end.
Thus, Î±-linolenic acid is a polyunsaturated ''n''â3 (omega-3) fatty acid. It
is an isomer of gamma-linolenic acid, a polyunsaturated ''n''â6 (omega-6)
fatty acid.
